attributes.title: Oral vitamin D supplementation for psoriatic patients: a systematic review and meta-analysis

q1.value: Oral vitamin D supplementation for psoriatic patients: a systematic review and meta-analysis

q2.value: Xenophon Theodoridis, Maria Grammatikopoulou, Dimitrios P. Bogdanos

q3.value: The benignant effects of vitamin D are well-established. In particular, topical vitamin D therapies alone or combined with topical corticosteroids are used as a first-line medication choice for psoriasis. However, the effect of oral vitamin D supplements for psoriasis have never been meta-analyzed. Hence, we will analyze the effect of oral vitamin D supplements on PASI score changes of psoriatic patients.

q4.value: If oral vitamin D supplements are effective, the mean PASI score change will be reduced.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
A systematic literature review will be performed on electronic databases Pubmed, Embase, Cochrane Central and Google for the grey literature. Reference lists of the included studies will also be reviewed.
Two independent reviewers will review and assess the studies from their titles, abstracts, and full-texts. In case of disagreement between the two reviewers, it will be resolved by a third reviewer.
The inclusion criteria for this SR&MA will include:
1) adults participants (>=18 years)
2) diagnosed with any form of psoriasis
3) receiving oral supplement of vitamin D
4) with a placebo comparator

Articles in languages other than English, with a non-RCT design, involving children or animals will be excluded.
The primary outcome will be the mean change in PASI score in 6 months.
We will use random effects model, which accounts for studies heterogeneity.

q23.value: In case of missing data, we will try to contact the authors of the primary studies (RCTs) to obtain the additional data.

q1.value: Influence of Coronavirus (COVID-19) on political preferences

q2.value: Michał Białek, Agata Groyecka, Maciej Karwowski, Marta Kowal, Izabela Lebuda, Agnieszka Sorokowska, Piotr Sorokowski

q3.value: We intend to investigate how information about Coronavirus (COVID-19) influences political preferences in the United States and Poland.

q4.value:
Main hypothesis: The exposition to Coronavirus (COVID-19) increases the likelihood of voting for a conservative candidate in the upcoming Presidential elections in the USA and Poland.

It is predicted that this effect is mediated by conservatism: the exposition to COVID-19 increases the conservatism, which then translates into higher support to the conservative candidate.

Exploratory analyses contain the role of affect and personal need for structure.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Between-subject design. 

All participants will be invited to take part in a study, which consists of two independent parts. The first part includes rating short press reports, and the second part consists of a number of questionnaires regarding values and opinions (see the description below).

There will be two experimental groups. In both groups, participants will receive three press media reports. In the first group, participants will receive two neutral texts and one text about climate change. In the second group, participants will receive two neutral texts, and one text about Coronavirus (COVID-19).
All participants will be asked to rate the quality of given press reports. 

In the second part, all participants will be presented with the same questions regarding their conservatism, the personal need for structure, and positive and negative affect, as well as political preferences. Due to some specificities in elections in the US and Poland, questions regarding political preferences have to differ slightly.

 In the end, participants will provide information regarding basic socio-economic measures.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the two experimental groups (i.e., two neutral press reports and one press report about climate change, or two neutral press reports and one press report about Coronavirus).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The study will be conducted in two countries: the United States and Poland. In both countries, the presidential elections will be held in 2020 (Poland – May 2020, USA – November 2020). 

In total, 1100 participants (550 for each country) will be recruited with the help of an external survey company. Participants will be compensated for their participation.

Participants will be asked to participate in two ostensibly unrelated studies. After providing informed consent for participation, participants will be presented with three short press reports (either two neutral  and one about climate change, or two neutral and one about Coronavirus). Their task will be to rate the quality of the given press reports. We will not analyze the ratings of the press reports’ quality, as the goal of the first part of the study is merely to present participants either a press report about Coronavirus or not.
This manipulation will be followed by attention check (we will ask participants a single choice question regarding the content of each press report). 

In the second part of the study, participants will provide answers to three questionnaires (positive and negative affect, the personal need for structure, and conservatism), and declare their political preferences.

A short questionnaire about basic socio-economic measures will be placed at the end of the study.

q13.value: Our target sample is 1100 participants (2 x 550).

q14.value: As we hypothesize a mediation effect, assuming that activating the information about coronavirus will boost participants’ conservatism, which will then lead to higher support to a conservative candidate, we calculated the assumed sample size using D. Kenny’s MedPower, https://davidakenny.shinyapps.io/MedPower/, taking the smallest effect size of interest as the starting point, with assumed alpha = .05 and beta = 0.90. We assumed the a path (coronavirus  conservatism) to be weak (beta / partial r = .15, or an equivalent of Cohen’s d = .30), b path (conservatism  support for a conservative candidate) to be medium-to-strong (beta / partial r = .40) and c path (coronavirus  support for conservative candidate) to be weak-to-moderate (beta / partial r = .20). It resulted in a required sample size of N = 461 per country, but given the expected 10%-15% failure in the attention check, we plan to obtain the initial sample of 550 per each country.

question.value:
We will manipulate the content of one of the short press reports. Half of the participants will receive two neutral press reports and one press report about climate change, and the other half will receive two neutral press reports and one press report about Coronavirus (COVID-19).

1)	The firstgroup will receive the following press reports:
The new giant in Amazon
The new tallest tree in Amazon has been recently discovered. It is 88 meters (289 ft) tall, moreover, it is 50% taller than the previously considered as the tallest, Amazon’s tree. Although the tallest tree has been discovered between 2016 and 2018 by the Brazil’s National Institute for Space Research, in a coordinated project, during which the large swaths of the Amazon has been scanned, only recently the team of researchers actually measured the tree and claimed its title. Nevertheless, the ‘giant’ from Amazon is yet far behind the tallest tree in the world – Hyperion, from California, which is stated to be of 115.85 meters (380 ft) tall. Interestingly, the exact locations of those high kings are shrouded in mystery to prevent potential vandalism.


Can you fold my laptop please
An international team of researchers has announced a new development that can change the way our laptops work, and look like. The recent trend in mobile technology, which easily spread and conquered the 2019 tech market, was based on a simple idea – to allow users to fold their devices. Foldable mobile phones have won the hearts of many people, thus, it is not surprising that the next step must have been to create foldable laptops. Thanks to the innovative solutions, a 17-inch laptop with a touchscreen became a reality. Its designers hope that the laptop will pass the initial tests successfully, and the mass production and distribution will be possible before the end of June.


Climate change – will mankind become extinct?
Scientists from all around the world are in an agreement that climate change is a fact. The average temperatures are now rising faster than at many other times in the past. Ice is melting, and most glaciers are retrieving. This may lead not only to severe droughts in some regions, but also intense rainfalls in others. Such places as Venice could sink, and others may be at great risk of massive floods. Many predict that the devastating floods in XX century may happen again, and as a consequence, millions of people would die. Some even say that the death rate connected with climate change could reach up to 40% of the entire human population.

Attention check:
The first press report was about:
a)	A recently discovered tree in Amazon
b)	A recently discovered species of ants
c)	The deepest lake in the world

The second press report was about:
a)	Nanotechnology
b)	Newest iPad
c)	Foldable laptops

The third press report was about:
a)	Climate change
b)	Neanderthals in Africa
c)	Archeological findings in Ethiopia


2)	The second group will receive the following press reports:

The new giant in Amazon
The new tallest tree in Amazon has been recently discovered. It is 88 meters (289 ft) tall, moreover, it is 50% taller than the previously considered as the tallest, Amazon’s tree. Although the tallest tree has been discovered between 2016 and 2018 by the Brazil’s National Institute for Space Research, in a coordinated project, during which the large swaths of the Amazon has been scanned, only recently the team of researchers actually measured the tree and claimed its title. Nevertheless, the ‘giant’ from Amazon is yet far behind the tallest tree in the world – Hyperion, from California, which is stated to be of 115.85 meters (380 ft) tall. Interestingly, the exact locations of those high kings are shrouded in mystery to prevent potential vandalism.

Can you fold my laptop please
An international team of researchers has announced a new development that can change the way our laptops work, and look like. The recent trend in mobile technology, which easily spread and conquered the 2019 tech market, was based on a simple idea – to allow users to fold their devices. Foldable mobile phones have won the hearts of many people, thus, it is not surprising that the next step must have been to create foldable laptops. Thanks to the innovative solutions, a 17-inch laptop with a touchscreen became a reality. Its designers hope that the laptop will pass the initial tests successfully, and the mass production and distribution will be possible before the end of June.

Coronavirus – modern Black Death?
The novel coronavirus COVID-19 is now causing panic all around the world. It started in Wuhan, and as of the beginning of March, there have been more than 120 000 cases with a suspected disease, among which more than 4 000 people have died already. More dreadfully, among the victims of the virus are doctors, who – despite the danger, put their life at great risk and willingly take care of sick patients. But the Coronavirus takes no prisoners and has no mercy. Many compare it to the Black Death, which in the medieval Europe led to deaths of millions of people. Will the Coronavirus become a modern plague with such an unimaginable death rate, reaching up to 40% of the entire human population?

Attention check:
The first press report was about:
a)	A recently discovered tree in Amazon
b)	A recently discovered species of ants
c)	The deepest lake in the world

The second press report was about:
a)	Nanotechnology
b)	Newest iPad
c)	Foldable laptops

The third press report was about:
a)	Anti-vaccine movement 
b)	Outbreak of Coronavirus 
c)	Novel cancer treatment

Exploratory pre-registered variable: the personal need for structure (PNS)

Read each of the following statements and decide how much you agree with each according to your attitudes, beliefs, and experiences. It is important for you to realize that there are no “right” or “wrong” answers to these questions. People are different, and we are interested in how you feel. Please respond according to the following 6-point scale
Scale:
1 = strongly disagree
2 = moderately disagree
3 = slightly disagree
4 = slightly agree
5 = moderately agree
6 = strongly agree

1: It upsets me to go into a situation without knowing what I can expect from it
2: I’m not bothered by things that interrupt my daily routine
3: I enjoy having a clear and structured mode of life
4: I like to have a place for everything and everything in its place
5: I enjoy being spontaneous
6: I find that a well-ordered life with regular hours makes my life tedious
7: I don’t like situations that are uncertain
8: I hate to change my plans at the last minute
9: I hate to be with people who are unpredictable
10: I find that a consistent routine enables me to enjoy my life more
11: I enjoy the exhilaration of being in unpredictable situations
12: I become uncomfortable when the rules in a situation are not clear

[Polish version]
Przeczytaj poniższe stwierdzenia i zdecyduj, w jakim stopniu zgadzasz się z każdym z nich. Pamiętaj, że nie ma „dobrych” lub „złych” odpowiedzi. Ludzie różnią się od siebie, a dla nas jest bardzo ważne, abyś odpowiadał(a) szczerze. 

Odpowiadaj posługując się 6-punktową skalą

Skala:
1 = zdecydowanie się nie zgadzam
2 = raczej się nie zgadzam
3 = trochę się nie zgadzam
4 = trochę się zgadzam
5 = raczej się zgadzam
6 = zdecydowanie się zgadzam

1: Denerwuje mnie, kiedy znajduję się w sytuacjach, po których nie wiem czego mogę się spodziewać. 
2: Nie przeszkadzają mi rzeczy, które zakłócają moją codzienną rutynę.
3: Lubię mieć uporządkowany i ustrukturyzowany tryb życia.
4: Lubię mieć miejsce na wszystko i wszystko na swoim miejscu.
5: Lubię być spontaniczny(a).
6: Uważam, że uporządkowane życie z regularnym planem godzinowym sprawia, że moje życie jest nudne.
7: Nie lubię sytuacji, które są niepewne.
8: Nie znoszę zmieniać planów w ostatniej chwili.
9: Nie znoszę być z ludźmi, którzy są nieprzewidywalni.
10: Uważam, że konsekwentna rutyna pozwala mi bardziej cieszyć się życiem.
11: Cieszę się radością z bycia w nieprzewidzianych sytuacjach.
12: Czuję się nieswojo, gdy zasady w danej sytuacji nie są jasne.

We plan to conduct some exploratory analyses among these participants who plan to take part in the election (answer 1 in C2_USA and 3 in C2_PL), and in the total sample.

We are going to examine a mediation model with a binary IV (-1 = control, 1 = coronavirus), one continuous mediator (conservatism) and political preferences (DV) as dependent variables. The DV will be recoded into a continuous variable with the range 0-100. All participants who will declare voting for a candidate other than D. Trump (USA) and A. Duda (Poland) will obtain 0 on this scale. The remaining participants who will declare voting for D. Trump (Q2) or A. Duda (Q2) will obtain the value from Q3. The following SPSS syntax will be used, to create the variable:

compute US_Preferences = 0.
if Q2_USA=1 US_Preferences=Q3_USA. 
compute PL_preferences=0.
if Q2_PL=1 PL_preferences=Q3_PL.

All participants will be invited to take part in a study, which consists of two independent parts. The first part includes rating short press reports, and the second part consists of a number of questionnaires regarding values and opinions (see the description below).

There will be two experimental groups. In both groups, participants will receive three press media reports. In the first group, participants will receive two neutral texts and one text about climate change. In the second group, participants will receive two neutral texts, and one text about Coronavirus (COVID-19).
All participants will be asked to rate the quality of given press reports. 

In the second part, all participants will be presented with the same questions regarding their conservatism, the personal need for structure, and positive and negative affect, as well as political preferences. Due to some specificities in elections in the US and Poland, questions regarding political preferences have to differ slightly.

 In the end, participants will provide information regarding basic socio-economic measures.
registration_responses.q12.question:
The study will be conducted in two countries: the United States and Poland. In both countries, the presidential elections will be held in 2020 (Poland – May 2020, USA – November 2020). 

In total, 1100 participants (550 for each country) will be recruited with the help of an external survey company. Participants will be compensated for their participation.

Participants will be asked to participate in two ostensibly unrelated studies. After providing informed consent for participation, participants will be presented with three short press reports (either two neutral  and one about climate change, or two neutral and one about Coronavirus). Their task will be to rate the quality of the given press reports. We will not analyze the ratings of the press reports’ quality, as the goal of the first part of the study is merely to present participants either a press report about Coronavirus or not.
This manipulation will be followed by attention check (we will ask participants a single choice question regarding the content of each press report). 

In the second part of the study, participants will provide answers to three questionnaires (positive and negative affect, the personal need for structure, and conservatism), and declare their political preferences.

A short questionnaire about basic socio-economic measures will be placed at the end of the study.
registration_responses.q16.question:
We will manipulate the content of one of the short press reports. Half of the participants will receive two neutral press reports and one press report about climate change, and the other half will receive two neutral press reports and one press report about Coronavirus (COVID-19).

1)	The firstgroup will receive the following press reports:
The new giant in Amazon
The new tallest tree in Amazon has been recently discovered. It is 88 meters (289 ft) tall, moreover, it is 50% taller than the previously considered as the tallest, Amazon’s tree. Although the tallest tree has been discovered between 2016 and 2018 by the Brazil’s National Institute for Space Research, in a coordinated project, during which the large swaths of the Amazon has been scanned, only recently the team of researchers actually measured the tree and claimed its title. Nevertheless, the ‘giant’ from Amazon is yet far behind the tallest tree in the world – Hyperion, from California, which is stated to be of 115.85 meters (380 ft) tall. Interestingly, the exact locations of those high kings are shrouded in mystery to prevent potential vandalism.


Can you fold my laptop please
An international team of researchers has announced a new development that can change the way our laptops work, and look like. The recent trend in mobile technology, which easily spread and conquered the 2019 tech market, was based on a simple idea – to allow users to fold their devices. Foldable mobile phones have won the hearts of many people, thus, it is not surprising that the next step must have been to create foldable laptops. Thanks to the innovative solutions, a 17-inch laptop with a touchscreen became a reality. Its designers hope that the laptop will pass the initial tests successfully, and the mass production and distribution will be possible before the end of June.


Climate change – will mankind become extinct?
Scientists from all around the world are in an agreement that climate change is a fact. The average temperatures are now rising faster than at many other times in the past. Ice is melting, and most glaciers are retrieving. This may lead not only to severe droughts in some regions, but also intense rainfalls in others. Such places as Venice could sink, and others may be at great risk of massive floods. Many predict that the devastating floods in XX century may happen again, and as a consequence, millions of people would die. Some even say that the death rate connected with climate change could reach up to 40% of the entire human population.

attributes.title: Black women's perceptions of managers who disclose struggling during COVID-19 pandemic
attributes.description: The current experiment aims to explore whether perceptions of shared adversity is an important mechanism underscoring Black women’s identification with a senior manager, and whether identifying with a senior manager encourages belonging, trust, and interest in a company. More broadly, this current experiment hopes to establish whether having a senior manager acknowledge her struggles and anxiety resulting from the current COVID-19 crisis encourages a stronger connection with that manager, and belonging, trust, and interest in the manager’s company. For this experiment, Black female participants will be randomly assigned to learn about a Black or White female senior manager, who either does or does not disclose facing challenges during the COVID-19 pandemic. We anticipate that Black women identify more strongly with a manager is Black relative to White, and a manager who discloses a past struggle versus does to disclose this information.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Black women's perceptions of managers who disclose struggling during COVID-19 pandemic: Exploring Black women's perceptions of a Black versus White female manager, who discloses versus not disclose that she is struggling during the current pademic.

other.value:
If we find that condition influences the perceptions of the percentage of Black and/or female employees at the company, we will run supplemental ANCOVAs controlling for these perceptions as covariates.

Because we are measuring job pursuit intentions for Uptown Consulting, and given the current economic uncertainty, we will explore whether our effects are moderated by current employment status, and/or feelings of uncertainty at one’s current job/ feelings of uncertainty about finding a job. However, we do not anticipate our effects will be moderated by these measures. 

We also will examine whether our effects are moderated by perceptions that the Black community is particularly harmed by COVID-19. It is possible that our effects (for both race and struggle condition) may be stronger for individuals who score higher on this measures. However, this is a very exploratory analysis.

Finally, we are measuring beliefs about social distancing at the beginning of the study and after participants read about the senior manager. We are curious whether reading about the importance of social distancing at Uptown Consulting will change these beliefs, and whether learning about a senior manager who shares participants’ racial identity and/or who discloses past struggles will result in stronger beliefs that social distancing is important.

sample.value: We have not run this exact study/ design in previous work, and thus, had to rely on broadly similar past research. Specifically, recent work (Pietri, Drawbaugh, Lewis, & Johnson, 2019), looked at anticipated belonging in a STEM company among Latinas, and also employed a 2 by 2 design (i.e., 2 [ethnicity] by 2 [gender] design). In this experiment, there was a significant effect of ethnicity (partial η-squared = 0.055) on belonging. Based on this effect size, an a priori analyses using G*Power indicated that for 4 groups and 2 time points (e.g., the 2 [time] x 2 [race] x 2 [struggle condition] design), to detect an effect at p< .05 and at 80% power, we would need at least 148 participants. A second a priori analyses using G*Power indicated that for 4 groups with 1 degree of freedom in the numerator (e.g., the 2 [race] x 2 [struggle condition] design), to detect an effect at p< .05 and at 80% power, we would need at least 137 participants. Because we were unsure of the effect size of the disclosed struggle condition versus not, we doubled required number of participants, and plan to recruit 300 participants. This higher number of participants will also allow us to exclude participants who do not identify as Black women, or fail any attention checks.

analyses.value:
For the majority of outcome measures, our study will have a 2 (race condition) by 2 (discloses struggles vs not) design. Thus, we will run between-subjects ANOVAs with race and struggle condition as predictors, and we anticipate main effects of both of these conditions.

For belonging, trust and comfort, and job interest, we will assess these outcomes at two time points (i.e., before learning about the senior manager and after learning about the senior manager). Thus, for these outcomes, we will have a 2 (time) by 2 (race condition) by 2 (discloses struggles vs not design) design. We will run mixed model ANOVAS for these outcomes, with time as a within-subjects variable, and race and struggle condition as between-subjects variables. We anticipate a main effect of time as well as main effects of race, and struggle condition.

We also will look at the correlations between all the outcome variables.

outliers.value:
We will include two easy attention check questions after participants read about the senior manager. (i.e., “who was the person you just read about” and “what was the race of the person you just read about”). We will exclude participants who fail these attention checks.
As mentioned above we will ask participants to briefly describe their impression of the senior manager. We will exclude participants who put nonsensical answers for this question (e.g., “impressive” “very nice study” “prime survey ideas”).

dependent.value:
For all of the following outcome measures, we will average the items, with higher scores indicating more of the measured constructs. 

Black female participants will begin the experiment by completing a measure assessing their beliefs about social distancing in order to stop the spread of COVID-19 (4 items). 

Participants will then be presented with a fictional company called “Uptown Consulting” and will see the website homepage associated with this company. Participants will be informed that after viewing the website, they will answer “various questions related to how you would feel if you were working at the company”. We will then assess participants initial anticipated belonging at the company (3 items), initial trust and comfort at the company (4 items), and their job pursuit intentions for the company (5 items).

Next, participants will be assigned to one of 4 company conditions. Specifically, participants will learn about a White or Black female senior manager, who discloses struggling during the COVID-19 pandemic, or does not disclose this information. All of the senior managers will discuss Uptown Consulting’s new work from home policies. 

Participants then will complete a series of measures assessing their impressions of the senior manager. Specifically, participants will indicate a) the extent to which they believe the manager has faced past bias (4 items), b) the extent to which they think the manager has had similar experiences of adversity (4 items) and similar experiences generally (2 items) as themselves, c) their sense of self-other overlap with the manager (8 items), d) the extent to which they believe the manager is an ally for Black individuals (2 items), and e) the extent to which they perceive the manager has having a similar perspective as themselves generally (3 items) and having a similar perspective about COVID-19 (3 items).

Finally, participants will be given a short open-ended question to describe their general impressions of the manager. Participants will be instructed to “Please briefly describe your impression of Mary Evans (the senior manager you just read about at Uptown Consulting). For instance, what you remember about the Mary and what stood out to you about Mary.”

All participants will then be presented with the Uptown Consulting website a second time, and asked to imagine how they would feel being an employee at the company now that they have read about the senior manager and her response to COVID-19. Participants will then indicate their anticipated belonging at the company (3 items), trust and comfort at the company (4 items), and their job pursuit intentions for the company (5 items). We also will assess participants’ perceptions of procedural justice for Black employees at the company (4 items), and anticipated job security at the company (3 items). Finally, we will measure the percentage of Black and female employees participants perceive work at the company. 

After completing measures related to Uptown Consulting, participants will again complete a measure assessing their beliefs about social distancing in order to stop the spread of COVID-19 (i.e., the same measure they completed at the beginning of the study; 4 items). Participants also will complete a measure assessing their perceptions that the Black community is particularly harmed/ at risk for COVID-19 (2 items). We also will assess how anxious (3 items) and depressed (3 items) participants felt in the last 24 hours. Given the current economic uncertainty and unemployment rate, we will ask participants about their current employment status. For those who are employed at least part-time, we will measure their job uncertainty (3 items), and for those who are unemployed, we will assess their uncertainty about finding a job in the near future.

conditions.value: There will be four conditions – a Black woman, who discloses her struggles; a Black woman, who does not disclose her struggles, a White woman who discloses her struggles, a White woman who does not disclose her struggles. 75 participants will be assigned to each condition.

hypothesis.value:
The primary goal of this experiment is to explore whether perceptions of shared adversity is an important mechanism underscoring Black women’s identification with a senior manager, and whether identifying with a senior manager encourages belonging, trust, and interest in a company. A secondary goal was to examine whether having a senior manager acknowledge her struggles and anxiety resulting from the current COVID-19 crisis encourages a stronger connection with that manager, and belonging, trust, and interest in the manager’s company.

Previous research has found that Black women identify more strongly and anticipant more belonging in an organization when they learn about a Black male or female successful employee at that company compared to a White female employee. That is, a successful employee with an overlapping racial identity is a more effective identity-safe cue than an employee with only an overlapping gender identity. Previous work on intersectional identities has established that Black women are more sensitive to racism then sexism. Thus, Black women are more likely to believe that Black employees have had similar experiences with past bias/adversity than White female employees. These similar experiences, in turn, relate to higher identification with the Black employee, and identifying with a successful employee ultimately encourages more interest and comfort in that employee’s company. 

The current research will explore whether having a White woman disclose shared adversity and struggles helps her act as an identity-safe cue for Black women. More broadly, the current research also will suggest different strategies that organizations might employee to signal they care about their employees during the COVID-19 pandemic. Specifically, in the current study, participants will learn about a Black or White female senior manager, who either does or does not acknowledge that she is struggling during the COVID-19 pandemic. Of note, across all conditions, the manager will discuss the company’s new work from home policies that were implemented to ensure the safety of the company’s employees. 

For perceptions of the manager, we are predicting two main effects (i.e., a main effect of race, and a main effect of disclosing past struggles or not).

That is, we anticipate that Black female participants will perceive a Black female manager as having faced more similar experiences with adversity/bias than a White female manager.

We also expect that Black female participants will perceive the manager who discloses struggling during the COVID-19 pandemic as having faced more similar experiences with adversity/bias than a manager who does not disclose these challenges.

We predict that Black female participants will feel more similar to a Black female manager than a White female manager.

Finally, we predict that Black female participants will feel more similar to a manager who discloses struggling during the COVID-19 pandemic compared to a manager who does not disclose these challenges.

We will assess belonging, trust and comfort, and interest in the company immediately after participants first view the company website and after participants learn about the senior manager. Thus, we can assess whether learning about the company’s work from home policy generally encourages more positive perceptions of the company. We anticipate a main effect of time, race, and disclosing past struggles. 

Specifically, we predict that relative to before learning about the policies, Black female participants will anticipate more belonging and trust and be more interested in working at the company after learning about the senior manager and the work from home company policies.

We also hypothesize that Black female participants will anticipate more belonging and trust and be more interested in working at the company when they learn about a Black female manager than a White female manager.

Finally, we expect that Black female participants will anticipate more belonging and trust, and be more interested in working at the company when they learn about a manager who discloses struggling during the COVID-19 pandemic compared to a manager who does not disclose these challenges.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
registration_responses.name: Black women's perceptions of managers who disclose struggling during COVID-19 pandemic: Exploring Black women's perceptions of a Black versus White female manager, who discloses versus not disclose that she is struggling during the current pademic.
registration_responses.other:
If we find that condition influences the perceptions of the percentage of Black and/or female employees at the company, we will run supplemental ANCOVAs controlling for these perceptions as covariates.

Because we are measuring job pursuit intentions for Uptown Consulting, and given the current economic uncertainty, we will explore whether our effects are moderated by current employment status, and/or feelings of uncertainty at one’s current job/ feelings of uncertainty about finding a job. However, we do not anticipate our effects will be moderated by these measures. 

We also will examine whether our effects are moderated by perceptions that the Black community is particularly harmed by COVID-19. It is possible that our effects (for both race and struggle condition) may be stronger for individuals who score higher on this measures. However, this is a very exploratory analysis.

Finally, we are measuring beliefs about social distancing at the beginning of the study and after participants read about the senior manager. We are curious whether reading about the importance of social distancing at Uptown Consulting will change these beliefs, and whether learning about a senior manager who shares participants’ racial identity and/or who discloses past struggles will result in stronger beliefs that social distancing is important.
registration_responses.sample: We have not run this exact study/ design in previous work, and thus, had to rely on broadly similar past research. Specifically, recent work (Pietri, Drawbaugh, Lewis, & Johnson, 2019), looked at anticipated belonging in a STEM company among Latinas, and also employed a 2 by 2 design (i.e., 2 [ethnicity] by 2 [gender] design). In this experiment, there was a significant effect of ethnicity (partial η-squared = 0.055) on belonging. Based on this effect size, an a priori analyses using G*Power indicated that for 4 groups and 2 time points (e.g., the 2 [time] x 2 [race] x 2 [struggle condition] design), to detect an effect at p< .05 and at 80% power, we would need at least 148 participants. A second a priori analyses using G*Power indicated that for 4 groups with 1 degree of freedom in the numerator (e.g., the 2 [race] x 2 [struggle condition] design), to detect an effect at p< .05 and at 80% power, we would need at least 137 participants. Because we were unsure of the effect size of the disclosed struggle condition versus not, we doubled required number of participants, and plan to recruit 300 participants. This higher number of participants will also allow us to exclude participants who do not identify as Black women, or fail any attention checks.
registration_responses.analyses:
For the majority of outcome measures, our study will have a 2 (race condition) by 2 (discloses struggles vs not) design. Thus, we will run between-subjects ANOVAs with race and struggle condition as predictors, and we anticipate main effects of both of these conditions.

For belonging, trust and comfort, and job interest, we will assess these outcomes at two time points (i.e., before learning about the senior manager and after learning about the senior manager). Thus, for these outcomes, we will have a 2 (time) by 2 (race condition) by 2 (discloses struggles vs not design) design. We will run mixed model ANOVAS for these outcomes, with time as a within-subjects variable, and race and struggle condition as between-subjects variables. We anticipate a main effect of time as well as main effects of race, and struggle condition.

We also will look at the correlations between all the outcome variables.
registration_responses.outliers:
We will include two easy attention check questions after participants read about the senior manager. (i.e., “who was the person you just read about” and “what was the race of the person you just read about”). We will exclude participants who fail these attention checks.
As mentioned above we will ask participants to briefly describe their impression of the senior manager. We will exclude participants who put nonsensical answers for this question (e.g., “impressive” “very nice study” “prime survey ideas”).
registration_responses.dependent:
For all of the following outcome measures, we will average the items, with higher scores indicating more of the measured constructs. 

Black female participants will begin the experiment by completing a measure assessing their beliefs about social distancing in order to stop the spread of COVID-19 (4 items). 

Participants will then be presented with a fictional company called “Uptown Consulting” and will see the website homepage associated with this company. Participants will be informed that after viewing the website, they will answer “various questions related to how you would feel if you were working at the company”. We will then assess participants initial anticipated belonging at the company (3 items), initial trust and comfort at the company (4 items), and their job pursuit intentions for the company (5 items).

Next, participants will be assigned to one of 4 company conditions. Specifically, participants will learn about a White or Black female senior manager, who discloses struggling during the COVID-19 pandemic, or does not disclose this information. All of the senior managers will discuss Uptown Consulting’s new work from home policies. 

Participants then will complete a series of measures assessing their impressions of the senior manager. Specifically, participants will indicate a) the extent to which they believe the manager has faced past bias (4 items), b) the extent to which they think the manager has had similar experiences of adversity (4 items) and similar experiences generally (2 items) as themselves, c) their sense of self-other overlap with the manager (8 items), d) the extent to which they believe the manager is an ally for Black individuals (2 items), and e) the extent to which they perceive the manager has having a similar perspective as themselves generally (3 items) and having a similar perspective about COVID-19 (3 items).

Finally, participants will be given a short open-ended question to describe their general impressions of the manager. Participants will be instructed to “Please briefly describe your impression of Mary Evans (the senior manager you just read about at Uptown Consulting). For instance, what you remember about the Mary and what stood out to you about Mary.”

All participants will then be presented with the Uptown Consulting website a second time, and asked to imagine how they would feel being an employee at the company now that they have read about the senior manager and her response to COVID-19. Participants will then indicate their anticipated belonging at the company (3 items), trust and comfort at the company (4 items), and their job pursuit intentions for the company (5 items). We also will assess participants’ perceptions of procedural justice for Black employees at the company (4 items), and anticipated job security at the company (3 items). Finally, we will measure the percentage of Black and female employees participants perceive work at the company. 

After completing measures related to Uptown Consulting, participants will again complete a measure assessing their beliefs about social distancing in order to stop the spread of COVID-19 (i.e., the same measure they completed at the beginning of the study; 4 items). Participants also will complete a measure assessing their perceptions that the Black community is particularly harmed/ at risk for COVID-19 (2 items). We also will assess how anxious (3 items) and depressed (3 items) participants felt in the last 24 hours. Given the current economic uncertainty and unemployment rate, we will ask participants about their current employment status. For those who are employed at least part-time, we will measure their job uncertainty (3 items), and for those who are unemployed, we will assess their uncertainty about finding a job in the near future.
registration_responses.conditions: There will be four conditions – a Black woman, who discloses her struggles; a Black woman, who does not disclose her struggles, a White woman who discloses her struggles, a White woman who does not disclose her struggles. 75 participants will be assigned to each condition.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
The primary goal of this experiment is to explore whether perceptions of shared adversity is an important mechanism underscoring Black women’s identification with a senior manager, and whether identifying with a senior manager encourages belonging, trust, and interest in a company. A secondary goal was to examine whether having a senior manager acknowledge her struggles and anxiety resulting from the current COVID-19 crisis encourages a stronger connection with that manager, and belonging, trust, and interest in the manager’s company.

Previous research has found that Black women identify more strongly and anticipant more belonging in an organization when they learn about a Black male or female successful employee at that company compared to a White female employee. That is, a successful employee with an overlapping racial identity is a more effective identity-safe cue than an employee with only an overlapping gender identity. Previous work on intersectional identities has established that Black women are more sensitive to racism then sexism. Thus, Black women are more likely to believe that Black employees have had similar experiences with past bias/adversity than White female employees. These similar experiences, in turn, relate to higher identification with the Black employee, and identifying with a successful employee ultimately encourages more interest and comfort in that employee’s company. 

The current research will explore whether having a White woman disclose shared adversity and struggles helps her act as an identity-safe cue for Black women. More broadly, the current research also will suggest different strategies that organizations might employee to signal they care about their employees during the COVID-19 pandemic. Specifically, in the current study, participants will learn about a Black or White female senior manager, who either does or does not acknowledge that she is struggling during the COVID-19 pandemic. Of note, across all conditions, the manager will discuss the company’s new work from home policies that were implemented to ensure the safety of the company’s employees.

Specifically, we predict that relative to before learning about the policies, Black female participants will anticipate more belonging and trust and be more interested in working at the company after learning about the senior manager and the work from home company policies.

Finally, we expect that Black female participants will anticipate more belonging and trust, and be more interested in working at the company when they learn about a manager who discloses struggling during the COVID-19 pandemic compared to a manager who does not disclose these challenges.

attributes.title: Power Analysis Behaviour Knowledge and Beliefs in Psychology
attributes.description: This is a pre-registration for my next PhD study which will ask psychological researchers about their experiences using (or not using power analysis). This study will include questions regarding the definition of power and power analysis, the ideal power for a study, and their own research behaviours when determining sample size.

q2.value: This is exploratory research which does not incorporate hypothesis testing. All outcome data will be descriptive in nature.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a survey for any global academic psychologists to take, delivered online via Qualtrics. Participants will be asked 'have you ever used power analysis' and their response will direct them to one of two survey branches: a branch which asks them why they have not used power analysis, or a branch that asks more about their power analysis experiences and understanding.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Human subjects, recruited online to access the survey via Qualtrics. Population: any global academic psychologists, including teaching/research staff without PhDs, and PhD students or equivalent level trainees. Links will be shared online to audiences on Twitter, Facebook, mailing lists, and groups within my university (Stirling). No rewards or payment for participant.

q11.value: There is no minimum sample size. The intention is to capture more than 100 academic psychologists, simply to work towards as representative a sample as possible.

q12.value: Power analysis is not appropriate as this is exploratory work. Constraints include access - academics are hard to engage with, particularly in research related to statistics. The recruitment time frame is 1 month, based on the current timeline of my PhD. Some issues such as low response are anticipated because of COVID 19.

q13.value: I will terminate data collection 1 month after launch (with launch anticipated in the second week of April). I will extend data collection if less than 100 responses have been collected.

question.value:
1. Approach to sample size - qualitative response
2. Experience using power analysis - yes/no
3. Proportion of previous research that has used power analysis (where appropriate) - % 
4. (if appropriate) Why power analysis was not used for all suitable studies - qualitative response or "why have you not used power analysis before?" - qualitative response
5. Post-hoc power experience (yes/no, followed by qualitative justification)
6. Software used for power analysis - free text response
7. Reasoning for effect size prediction - free text or multiple choice response
8. Define power - qualitative response
9. Opinion on acceptable and ideal power for psychological research - % slider responses
10. Opinion on how opportunity sampling might affect power - free text response
11. Rating importance of power analysis - multiple choice response
12. Personal rating of statistical knowledge - 1-10 slider response
13. Personal comments, thoughts and questions about power - free text response
14. Demographics: country location, academic position, sub field of psychology, engagement with open science movement

Descriptive analysis, divided by groups and other individual differences. Relationships between statistical knowledge and power analysis behaviours may be explored. All analysis is exploratory. No p-values will be calculated.

attributes.title: Functional outcome measurements in stroke Rehabilitation linked to ICF: systematic review
attributes.description: The work aims to identify outcome measurement scales that are used on functional assessment of stroke which have been linked to ICF.

q1.value: Functional outcome measurements in Stroke rehabilitation linked to ICF: systematic review

q3.value: Stroke is the second major cause of mortality worldwide and the survivors experience diverse limitations on their activities and restriction of their participation. According to the International Classification of Functioning disability and health (ICF) model, rehabilitation programs should focus on patient needs and expectations. To identify the patient's needs physiotherapists are encouraged to use specific validated scales according to the health condition of each patient. Most of these scales were published before the implementation of the ICF model by the World Health Organization and are still used nowadays. Some of these scales have already been linked to ICF domains, a process that should follow specific rules and aims to bring the scales to the language of the biopsychosocial model. This study pretend to identify which validated scales were already been linked to the ICF model in the stroke adult population.

q4.value: There are some specific scales to stroke populations that were already linked to the ICF model of rehabilitation.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: Not applicable once the study is a systematic review.

question.value: The registration study is a systematic review of the literature about the existing scales to functional outcome measurements specific to the stroke population which has already been linked to the ICF model. This review will be structured according to the PRISMA and the protocol will be registered at PROSPERO and OSF.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
This systematic review will be conducted by searching the following electronic databases: MEDLINE, LILACS, DITAS, SCIELO, PHYSCHINFO, PUBMED. Bibliographical and key author searches from the included studies will be used to expand the search for other appropriate articles. 
Studies of any design will be included if they address 1) the stroke population; 2) the functional outcome measurements used in stroke rehabilitation and 3) functional outcome measurements that have been linked to ICF. Studies will be excluded if they are expert opinion, case reports or if just the abstract is available.
Articles of any language and data will be included.

q13.value: Once the study is a systematic review we will include all articles that match the inclusion criteria and exclude the ones that do not follow these criteria. A flowchart will be outlined to detail the number of articles included in the analysis.

question.value: Not applicable to the study.
The number of articles that include inclusion criteria: 1. stroke population, 2. functional outcome measurements and 3. ICF linking

Two independent reviewers will work on the data extraction that will assess if articles fit the inclusion and exclusion criteria. When considered eligible, articles will be included in this study. A third reviewer will be consulted if there is no consensus. 
A narrative synthesis will be carried out where the linkage to ICF of the scales will be described. After, the authors will conduct a descriptive synthesis of the assessed ICF domains of the scales that were already linked to ICF.

attributes.title: Konsep Sekolah Efektif Dan Proses Perbaikan Mutu Pendidikan Di Indonesia

summary.value: Keunggulan suatu bangsa tidak lagi bertumpu pada kekayaan alam, melainkan pada keunggulan sumber daya manusia (SDM), yaitu tenaga terdidik yang mampu menjawab tantangan tantangan yang sangat cepat. Kenyataan ini sudah lebih dari cukup untuk mendorong pakar dan praktisi pendidikan melakukan kajian sistematik untuk membenahi atau memperbaiki sistem pendidikan nasional. Agar keluaran sekolah mampu beradaptasi secara dinamis dengan perubahan dan tantangan itu, pemerintah melontarkan gagasan tentang manajemen pendidikan yang berbasis sekolah (school-based management) yang memberikan ruang yang luas bagi sekolah dan masyarakatnya untuk menentukan program dan rencana pengembangan diri sesuai dengan kebutuhan dan kondisi masing masing. Efektifitas sekolah menunjukan adanya proses perekayasaan berbagai sumber dan metode yang diarahkan pada terjadinya pembelajaran disekolah secara optimal. Efektifitas sekolah merujuk pada pemberdayaan semua komponen sekolah sebagai organisasi tempat belajar berdasarkan tugas pokok dan fungsinya masing-masing dalam struktur program dengan tujuan agar siswa belajar dan mencapai hasil yang telah ditetapkan, yaitu memiliki kompetensi. Pada sekolah efektif, semua siswa baik siswa yang mempunyai kemampuan tinggi dalam belajar, yang dapat mengembangkan diri, siswa yang memiliki kemampuan intelektualitas yang biasapun dapat mengembangkan dirinya, jika dibandingkan dengan kondisi awal ketika mereka baru memasuki sekolah. Jadi konsep sekolah efektif adalah sekolah yang mampu mengoptimalkan semua masukan dan proses bagi ketercapaian output pendidikan, yaitu prestasi sekolah terutama prestasi siswa yang ditandai dengan dimilikinya semua kemampuan berupa kompetensi yang dipersyaratkan didalam belajar.

attributes.title: Humanitarian Assistance to Refugees in Turkey

q1.value: Humanitarian Assistance to Refugees in Turkey

q2.value: Berk Özler | Scott Cunningham | Facundo P. Cuevas

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Turkey is host to more than three million refugees, mostly originating from Syria and a minority coming from Iraq and Afghanistan. This makes Turkey the top refugee hosting country in the world (UNHCR 2017). Turkey’s response to the refugee crisis is highlighted for its development approach, which includes a non-camp solution to the refugee influx (World Bank 2015). Refugees in Turkey can obtain identity cards, access to services and an employer-sponsored work permit. A reduced share, at less than 10 percent, live in camps near the Syrian border. In November 2016, the Emergency Social Safety Net (ESSN), a refugee cash assistance program, was introduced with financial support from the European Union’s (EU) Facility for Refugees in Turkey (FRiT) through its humanitarian arm, The Directorate-General for European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations (ECHO). The program is implemented in partnership with the Ministry of Family and Social Policies (MoFSP), the World Food Programme (WFP), and the Turkish Red Crescent (TRC) as a complementary program to the national social assistance scheme for Turkish citizens. The ESSN benefits from the coordination of the national Disaster and Emergency Management Presidency (AFAD), an institution working to prevent disasters, coordinate post-disaster response, and promote cooperation among various government agencies in Turkey. This study assesses the impact of ESSN on the welfare of its beneficiaries using panel data from three rounds of data collection (baseline, midline, and endline).

q16.value: We will estimate the ITT effects of cash transfers to refugees in Turkey on their outcomes relating to consumption, food security, children’s schooling, and labor market outcomes, as described in the attached documents (PAP and background document).

q17.value: The main identification strategy is propensity score matching, which has been specified using baseline data before researchers had access to follow-up rounds of data. Robustness of impact findings using this approach will be tested using nearest-neighbor matching and coarsened exact matching, the exact models for which have not yet been specified.

registration_responses.q1: Humanitarian Assistance to Refugees in Turkey
registration_responses.q2: Berk Özler | Scott Cunningham | Facundo P. Cuevas
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data
registration_responses.q15: Turkey is host to more than three million refugees, mostly originating from Syria and a minority coming from Iraq and Afghanistan. This makes Turkey the top refugee hosting country in the world (UNHCR 2017). Turkey’s response to the refugee crisis is highlighted for its development approach, which includes a non-camp solution to the refugee influx (World Bank 2015). Refugees in Turkey can obtain identity cards, access to services and an employer-sponsored work permit. A reduced share, at less than 10 percent, live in camps near the Syrian border. In November 2016, the Emergency Social Safety Net (ESSN), a refugee cash assistance program, was introduced with financial support from the European Union’s (EU) Facility for Refugees in Turkey (FRiT) through its humanitarian arm, The Directorate-General for European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations (ECHO). The program is implemented in partnership with the Ministry of Family and Social Policies (MoFSP), the World Food Programme (WFP), and the Turkish Red Crescent (TRC) as a complementary program to the national social assistance scheme for Turkish citizens. The ESSN benefits from the coordination of the national Disaster and Emergency Management Presidency (AFAD), an institution working to prevent disasters, coordinate post-disaster response, and promote cooperation among various government agencies in Turkey. This study assesses the impact of ESSN on the welfare of its beneficiaries using panel data from three rounds of data collection (baseline, midline, and endline).
registration_responses.q16: We will estimate the ITT effects of cash transfers to refugees in Turkey on their outcomes relating to consumption, food security, children’s schooling, and labor market outcomes, as described in the attached documents (PAP and background document).
registration_responses.q17: The main identification strategy is propensity score matching, which has been specified using baseline data before researchers had access to follow-up rounds of data. Robustness of impact findings using this approach will be tested using nearest-neighbor matching and coarsened exact matching, the exact models for which have not yet been specified.

attributes.title: Character Education for Gifted and Talented Pupils
attributes.description: Character Education for Gifted and Talented Pupils

copyright_holders: Kubra Kirca Demirbaga & Laura Mazzoli Smith

q1.value: Kubra Kirca Demirbaga, Laura Mazzoli Smith

q2.value: At the empirical layer, the desire to transform individual potential into societal gain was found to be the causal mechanism shaping teachers’ views about the character education of gifted and talented pupils.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The empirical data consists of ten focus-group interviews conducted with 48 teachers who work in Science and Art Centres in six different geographical regions of Turkey.

q8.value: Registration following analysis of the data

question.value: The data were collected from six different geographical regions of Turkey, ten different Science and Art Centers (SAC). In selecting the SACs for the sample, the location of the cities in different regions was considered, and SACs with more students and teachers was part of the sampling strategy, along with geographical spread.Ten focus-group interviews conducted with 48 teachers: one group consists of three teachers, other nine group consists of five teachers. Although each focus group consisted of teachers in different domains (science, social science, language, music and arts, computer science, primary school teacher, psychological counselor), they all work with only gifted and talented pupils and across all levels, primary, secondary and high school, except pre-primary school teachers. For these focus-groups, twelve semi-structured interview questions were prepared to allow discussion on questions (these questions were also uploaded to the OSF system).

q11.value: Ten focus-group interviews conducted with 48 teachers: one group consists of three teachers, other nine group consists of five teachers.

question.value: The top level coding (micro-, meso-, and macro-level) generated three demi-regularities, which can be understood as partial regularities indicating actualization of a mechanism in a specific context: (1) the instrumental conception that character education is important for gifted and talented pupils in order to be able to utilize their high potential for the benefit of society; (2) the functionalist conception that character education is important for gifted and talented pupils because they will be role models for society due to their future positions in science, art, and the management of the country; and (3) the developmental conception that character education is important for gifted and talented pupils in terms of their own socio-emotional development.

This study was analyzed in a qualitative way by using a critical realist approach. Critical realist approach provided to go beyond the empirical data (that is the answers of the teachers). We have examined how empirical data on the character education of gifted and talented pupils could be analyzed to arrive at a causal mechanism. By examining the powers and liabilities of macro- and micro-level entities in relation to the data discussed here, and employing the three-stage critical realist methodology of identification of demi-regularities, abduction and retroduction.
